Award.AwardTitle: IGERT: New Mathematical Tools for Next Generation Materials

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This Integrative Graduate Education and Research Training (IGERT) award supports the establishment of a multidisciplinary, multi-institutional program for graduate training in next generation computational and analytical tools for materials science. This program will be based at Texas A&M University, in partnership with Prairie View A&M University, Texas State University, and six other academic institutions. One of the major goals will be to supply doctoral students with analytical tools and instill in them the broad-based understanding that will be needed for future advances in materials design. Research themes include design of new materials by incorporating nanometer-scale components and combining different functional properties, and development of new ways to analyze the large-scale behavior of such materials by incorporating knowledge of their atomic- and nanometer-scale properties. The program draws upon a group of cutting-edge materials researchers and experts in mathematics and computational methodology at Texas A&M and the partner institutions. The training program will include a multi-disciplinary curriculum, cohort-based learning with co-location of students, and activities aimed at improving communications and awareness of social and diversity issues. Rotations between research groups in the first year will provide a jumpstart for students training. The partnership between principal institutions will allow interested and qualified Masters students to participate in collaborative research and selected IGERT activities and is a key component of the recruitment plan to attract a highly diverse group of well-qualified students. A mentoring committee will track the students and help tailor students IGERT experience to their career plans. IGERT is an NSF-wide program intended to meet the challenges of educating U.S. Ph.D. scientists and engineers with the interdisciplinary background, deep knowledge in a chosen discipline, and the technical, professional, and personal skills needed for the career demands of the future. The program is intended to catalyze a cultural change in graduate education by establishing innovative new models for graduate education and training in a fertile environment for collaborative research that transcends traditional disciplinary boundaries.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project “New Mathematical Tools for Next Generation Materials” funded under NSF Division of Graduate Education, at Texas A&M University, Prairie View A&M University, and Texas State University, focused on the development of interdisciplinary training programs for graduate students, and associated collaborative research efforts joining applied mathematics and materials science. This award brought together Applied Mathematicians studying new methods and algorithms to treat highly complex systems, such as new materials including large-scale defects and interfaces, and researchers from several departments focused on experimental/computational research and development for such materials. Curricular developments under this program led toward the establishment of new programs for students including the Interdisciplinary Ph.D. track in Mathematics, which began accepting students at Texas A&M in Spring 2009 and which has developed as an extremely successful part of the curriculum, aimed at students interested in focusing upon problems of immediate practical importance. Achievements of trainees and faculty members under this program also led to the establishment of a new Department of Materials Science and Engineering at Texas A&M in 2013.

 

A total of 44 trainees have been supported under this program, with 10 having graduated with Ph.D. from Texas A&M thus far, and 9 M.S. graduates from Texas State and Prairie View A&M, and with 18 currently progressing toward the Ph.D. degree. These trainees came from diverse backgrounds, have focused upon materials-related problems of national importance, and have won awards attesting the high caliber of their work, with graduates thus far are contributing in US academics, national labs, and industry. Among M.S. graduates, one has a college teaching position while the others are working in industry. Ph.D. graduates are now contributing through industrial research at Intel and GE Aviation, at National Laboratories, and in Academics. Awards and achievements by these graduates include the 2013 InerPore-Fraunhofer Award for Young Researchers, two NRC Postdoctoral Research Associateships and one Oak Ridge Institute for Science and Engineering Postdoctoral Fellowship awardees. Two of the graduates were awarded prestigious Association of Former Students Distinguished Graduate Student Awards for Excellence in Doctoral Research upon graduation from Texas A&M.

 

The collaborative research efforts supported under this award included many individual successes contributing to areas of national need, such as development of new metal alloys related to shape memory alloys, in which the magnetocaloric and elastocaloric effects may potentially be used for harvesting of otherwise wasted energy and for chloro-fluorocarbon-free refrigeration, a morphing tissue scaffold based on similar alloys which would provide support for cellular growth, much like a structural scaffold provides support for a building, and could stimulate pancreatic and bone cell growth, new models predicting when a cracked structure (such as a critical component in an airframe) is safe to continue in service or when it must be repaired or replaced, which are being tested and implemented by engineering groups in both Air Force and Army research laboratories, and a new type of high-temperature multifunctional composite, based on “MAX phase” ceramics, with potential operating conditions not previously attainable that may lead to applications in jet engine fittings and petroleum industry couplers.
